Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2018
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2018, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways. Understanding the process of speciation (how one distinct species becomes two distinct species) is fundamental to understanding the origins of biodiversity. Speciation is difficult to study because it cannot be directly observed within a human lifetime. One way to overcome this obstacle is to study how one species evolves across space rather than through time. One example of this approach is to look at a species that has a distribution range expanding around a barrier (e.g. a mountain range), and then determine if that species has evolved due to this break in distribution. This is known as a ring species and it is considered to be the perfect demonstration of speciation. Examples are rare but have had an outsized impact on our understanding of speciation. This research will expand our empirical understanding of ring species and in turn, the process of speciation, by rigorously documenting a promising, yet so far unappreciated ring species candidate, the Dusky-capped Flycatcher of Central and South America. This research will utilize and integrate a variety of biological collections including museum specimens, genetic resources, and audio collections of avian vocalizations.
In the Dusky-capped Flycatcher, two phenotypically and genetically divergent subspecies have distinct yet overlapping elevational distributions along the southern half of the Andes, yet are connected by a continuous ring of intermediate populations in the lowlands surrounding the impermeable barrier of the northern Andes. To characterize the phenotypic variation of this potential ring species, the fellow will collect data on morphology and plumage color from a remarkable series of historical museum specimens. Importantly, every specimen is linked to archived audio recordings made at the time of their collection permitting an integrated evaluation of plumage, morphology, and vocalizations. Secondly, a reference genome and accompanying lower-coverage genomes will be assembled from existing genetic resources. These genomes will be used to test the genetic predictions of the ring species hypothesis. The impact of this research will extend beyond its intellectual contributions to the broader public through involvement and mentorship of students from underrepresented groups. The results of this research will be disseminated through peer-reviewed publications as well as a public education campaign through the fellow's host institution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the how species form, known as the process of speciation, is a fundamental goal of evolutionary biology. Speciation is difficult to study because it is a continuous process that occurs over time spans that are generally much greater than recorded human history. As such, only a single point in this process can be observed for a given lineage undergoing or having undergone speciation. One tractable solution to this conundrum is to think of variation within a species that is distributed across geographic space as representative of different stages in time of the speciation process. The phenomenon of a ring species is the perfect evolutionary scenario to leverage this idea. Imagine a species that varies in its appearance gradually across geographic spaces creating two extremes connected by intermediates. Now, imagine that this gradient in appearance were to extend around a geographic barrier, like a mountain range or large body of water, until the extremes overlap geographically. If these two overlapping populations did not recognize each other as the same species due to their different appearances, but are still connected by a chain of intermediate populations, this is a ring species.

Studies of ring species have had an outsized impact on the field of speciation research yet there are few solid examples. As an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Biology, my overall goal was to integrate genomic, phenotypic, behavioral, and ecological data derived from biological collections to evaluate a promising ring species candidate, the tyrant flycatcher Myiarchus tuberculifer. In tropical South America, this species forms a ring of gradual variation in morphology and plumage in the lowlands surrounding the northern Andes (Colombia and Ecuador). It’s distribution also extends into the highlands of the southern Andes where it exhibits a discrete break in these characters between the Andean highland form and lowland Amazonian form, the ends of a potential ring species. The project had two specific objectives. Objective 1 – Characterize phenotypic stages of ring speciation through the quantification of geographic variation in plumage, morphology, and vocalizations. Objective 2 – Test genetic predictions for a ring species using whole genomes and demographic model selection.

I assembled two complementary datasets to accomplish these two principal objectives. The first was a database of quantitative metrics of morphology and plumage from 421 specimens and measurements of vocal variation from 6497 unique vocalizations representing 300 distinct individuals. In parallel, I identified 26 million genetic variants from the genomes of 136 individuals strategically selected to test the ring species hypothesis. Using these two datasets I tested the hypothesis that M. tuberculifer is a ring species by addressing three key questions. 1 – Does a contact zone exist between the Amazonian lowland and Andean highland forms in the southern Andes? 2 – Are the highland and lowland forms reproductively isolated? 3 – Are the ends of this potential rings species bridged by gradual geographic morphological, plumage, and genetic variation?

I found that birds from the highlands were both bigger and darker crowned than the lowland birds and that the variation in these characters was not gradual but rather clustered. Further, specimens at middle elevations could not be unambiguously assigned to either population. However, the genetic data showed that, for most of the length of the southern Andes, there were two discrete genetic clusters occupying the high and low elevations and which came into contact at middle elevations. This same genetic data also allowed me to determine that there was very little gene flow between the highland and lowland forms suggesting reproductive isolation. Finally, I found the expected pattern of isolation-by-distance around the hypothesized ring. That is, samples closer geographically together as measured around the hypothesized ring, were more closely related to each other genetically. In contrast the null hypothesis of isolation-by-distance based on straight-line distances was not supported.

The two large datasets I assembled allowed me to affirm the three key predictions of ring speciation in M. tuberculifer. These results provide evidence for the first ring species in South America and one of the handful that have been well-documented. This study was only possible through the use of biological collections and will serve as an example to other researchers of the scientific potential of museums.
